A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field
The multiplicative group of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group formed by all nonzero elements of $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_q^*\]$. It is cyclic of order $q-1$.
Does the concept of a/an p-group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a p-group is defined as a group whose order is a power of a prime number p. On the other hand, the multiplicative group of a finite field $\mathbb{F}_q^*$ consists of all nonzero elements of the field $\mathbb{F}_q$, and it has order $q-1$. For $\mathbb{F}_q^*$ to be a p-group, $q-1$ must be a power of a prime number. However, $q-1$ being a power of a prime is not a general requirement for the definition or existence of $\mathbb{F}_q^*$. The order $q-1$ can be any integer that results from subtracting one from a prime power q, and it does not necessarily have to be a power of a prime itself. Therefore, the concept of a p-group is not necessary for the definition or understanding of the multiplicative group of a finite field. The definition of $\mathbb{F}_q^*$ stands independently of whether $q-1$ is a power of a prime or not.
